reviewText:
This is either a borderline unplayable nightmare or an excellent and deeply realistic training simulator for attempting to enter a house guarded by three vicious dogs in a world free from the laws of physics, space, time and reason.

After being killed by reading a note and having the game restart me upside down twice, I am forced to conclude the former.

Allow me to share my suffering.

reviewText:
To put it simple, Red Lake is the spiritual successor of The Slaughtering Grounds, but in his own way...

With six chapters that offer some varieties Red Lake could be an interesting game to play but sadly that's not the case since the game also comes with a variety of bugs and issues.

First of all, the enemies are badly designed and poorly animated. Also, the interior environments need lot of works. The only thing that stands out is the forest which is not that bad for an indie game.

Aside from the graphics, the presentation itself has nothing positive neither. The cutscenes look so amateurish as is the voice-over.

Throughout the game you will only carry a pistol. Its shooting rate is so ridiculously low that it's not even fun to use. Anyway, there's not many thing to shoot at except zombie dogs, crystal tigers and annoying crows.

Again, the worst part of the game is not the combat itself but the travelling or backtracking or whatever you call it. Chapter 5 is the most frustrating part of the game. Once you get there (if you haven't gave up before) you will know what I'm talking about.

Overall, this game will only please people who already has a big collection of bad games in their Steam library. Red Lake requires lot of patience. If you don't have much experience with horrendous indie games start with some Digital Homicide Studios games (The Slaugthering Grounds, Deadly Profits).

If you want to get an idea of what the game looks like you can watch my videos playthrough by clicking on the following link :

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUcvRJfF0f8D9XveC-YP5L6NOzdoEFNmn

Rating :
1.5

reviewText: Wow...this game was amazingly bad. First of all the animations of the dogs you first encounter are bad. I shot one, and his corpse did somersaults at my feet. In a wacky game like goat simulator that may be acceptable, but not here. When you die you respawn at a checkpoint, but the ammo you had does not respawn with you, so if you run out of bullets dying will not bring them back. There were plenty of times that the dogs were a mile away, but still managed to bite me. I would hear the barks after I died. Game is glitchy and full of bugs. When you run, the stamina meter depletes very quickly, and your character will go into an asthmatic attack. I did not make it too far, could not figure out where to go or what to do. I lost interest quick as I found the game painfully dull. A masterclass in crappy game design and execution. Not worth it.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BMDDTRaO8DU&index=37&list=PLNCk-m24qgLkgLn0G_PjSKus4gRPcU69J

reviewText:
You're an agent sent to discover what's happening near a Siberian lake that purposedly turned red and started affecting the local wildlife: to do so you'll have to survive rabid zombie dogs and weird instakill azure spheres while reading cryptic notes.
Red Lake is a badly programmed game with poor production values, no atmosphere, bland gameplay and zero fun factor.

PROS:

-some bugs might help you progress, so yay I guess?

CONS:

-terrible graphics, the pixelated lights and overboard bloom are laughable

-jerky framerate

-embarassing sounds

-buggy physics

-lazy level design, you'll be seeing the same bushes and trees all around the place with a few assets thrown in

-zero atmosphere, just a few jump scares here and there, and some of them are hilariously bad

-frustrating difficulty made worse by the lack of checkpoints

-many bugs

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=632298224

As I started Red Lake I was welcomed by an intro where a narrator explained the game premise in badly accented English, sadly I'd not get most of what he said as the music was much higher than his voice and there's no option screen to adjust volume. After that you're thrown in a forested area, have to face a few dogs, read a note, nighttime suddendly comes and you're supposed to survive several dogs in a row.

Well, sadly the gunplay is terrible, the pistol fires slowly and, if you want to flee as the dev suggests, your stamina bar depletes laughably fast (just like your flashlight). Did you die to the dogs after playing for 15ish mins? Well sorry but it's back to square one and you'll have to do everything again. If you're unlucky you might spawn with no bullets at all, or less bullets that intended (I personally had 18, then 18 again, then zero, then 40), or you might get stuck on a brick or on the nose of a dog and thus find yourself a metre above ground. If you're lucky though the second chapter will unlock after you die a couple times and you can enjoy trying to sneak through a zone inhabited by many instakill azure balls of energy.

Red Lake simply isn't worth any kind of money nor an install if you got it from a bundle...it's simply a terrible game and its frustrating gameplay and gamebreaking bugs make it miss even the so bad it's hilarious" category."

reviewText:
Ok, so I was looking for a new horror game to get to grips with on my horror channel and I came across this game that not many others had played. At £3.99 I thought it would be fine and not a waste if it wasn't very good.

The start is faily poor, not much going on, running makes me feel ill, very little stamina but then most characters in games these days seem to suffer from asthma. The translucent cat and man on the bridge were very poor and the level of graphics for a chargable game were less than I would expect.

However - when I look at the game as a whole, the gameplay, whether I was scared, the atmosphere created etc, it actually wasn't bad. It certainly wasn't an easy game to get through either. I spend several hours playing to get the 45 mins of edited gameplay for my channel. There were plenty of glitches but I put them to one side and carried on.

My main and final gripe with Red Lake was towards the end of the game (I assume its was near the end) when I was attacked and killed by the crows or by the silent black giant I was sent back to around half way through, so had to play another 40 mins just to get back to where I was before just to be killed again to have to replay 40 mins etc, etc....

I can forgive most things and in this game I had to but to be sent back so far was just too much and I gave up in frustration in the end. I'm not sure if everyone has had this glitch or if its just me?

Would I recommend this game...Yes if you didn't have to pay or if this glitch wasn't there! But as you do and it is my verdict is please don't buy it until the glitch has been sorted.

Watch my video to get a taster, then its up to you.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rk3b8RmSvIQ

reviewText:
I would like to be able to recommend this game because the premise seems good - a mystery/thriller story driven FPS.   A solid genre choice.

The artwork is a little low effort, but establishes theme well enough.   The game runs nice and smooth in 4K.

Unfortunately the bugs are too numerous to make the game enjoyable at all.

If you have a joystick or game controller plugged in, no matter how wide the deadzones, it will march you forward to the left constantly, which is distracting.

When you zoom in with the pistol, it's fine, but when you let go of the zoom control it snaps back instantly to unzoomed, really jarring.

When you die and restart the game, it doesn't reset your ammo levels!

The enemies in the game are really clumsy and badly animated.

I wish they had written the game properly, the idea looked interesting.  But it's just unplayable.

reviewText:
Red Lake is...  yes.

=======

CONS:

- Lack of intriguing story: The story is first and foremost, uninteresting. I felt bored listening to the opening monologue by the protagonist, and really don't recall why he was there in the first place. The only thing I noticed, was his voice.

- Choice of voice actor: He's not bad! Don't get me wrong; he's alright. The issue is... well, did they tell him to do an accent and then just drop it all together? Or did they just mess up? Also, what accent is he supposed to have?! Is it Russian or something? I only assume because of the Russian newsprint laying around, as well as the option to play it in Russian, other than English. Either way, it's distracting.

- Lack of weapons/choice of weapons: Why does he ONLY have a gun? He should really have a knife, or the use of his fists, if you run out of ammo. Losing ammo supply in this game means game-over, essentially. There really should be an additional weapon introduce, such as melee of some sort, instead of just the gun. It's not even a very good gun, either, as he has to shoot a dog in the face 5 times before it dies. Which brings me to another issue...

- Enemy AI: They automatically know where you are, and how to get to you, without you knowing where they are until you see them. If you CAN see them... maybe it was an aesthetic thing, but, it just looked lazy, wherein you enter the caves and see a polygonal figure of a cat/mountain lion thing(?) that looks like it wasn't finished, textured, coloured, or anything, and was just left, with the addition of some twinkly sounds (akin to wind chimes) thrown in to make them sound like they belong that way. I'm sorry... it looks lazy. Also, the mechanic for killing the giant electro-sphere, things? Well, I don't understand at all how that works. Shooting barrels does nothing but waste ammo for an already crummy pistol.

- World animation: The tree leaves and bushes look like they're jivin' to some crazy tunes, while the grass remains solid as a rock. Very distracting, and again, feels lazy.

- Fighting Mechanic: It works well enough, except... when a dog attacks, how come I can stand on it's face? At one point, I had a dog standing on it's hind linds, with me balancing on it's face, shooting it. Then, another dog jumped at me, so I was standing on the face of a vertically standing dog, who was standing on the face of another vertically standing dog! I don't know if that's what goes on in Russia or not, but... that's just odd.

- Landscape: Drab, unappealing, and boring. Straight up.

- Lack of Menu Settings: No settings, aside from initial boot-up resolution choices, and English or Russian language before starting a game. Disappointing.

- No Save/Load" feature: Not sure if it auto-saves or what
recommended: I'm not willing to find out.\n\n- Lack of Scares/Scares in general: This game wasn't impressive at all
hoursPlayed: when it came to getting a fright out of me. Mostly jump scares
voteText: all of which fell flat for me
helpfulPercent: were uninteresting. A floating head or a man disappearing from sight in a jittery black smoke-type thing (that was just awkward) might have worked well in 1995
votesHelpful: but not in 2015. At all. Nor did some giant metal barrels suddenly flinging themselves around bear any fear. Not even the floating head that just slid in through one wall
votesFunny: and into the next well. Just... no. That's
column18: I guess.\n\n- Flashlight: Why does the flashlight only work for a set time limit before needing to recharge? No battery system
column21: over a period of a good amount of time
column22: before using it again. That's just...  odd. No flashlights work like that unless they're manually rechargeable (winding)
column23:
and this one definitely isn't that kind.



PROS:

+ Textures (where applied

column26: and the foliage is well enough done. It looks good

column28: and serves it purpose.\n\n+ Music/Atmosphere: The music really sets the mood for the game

and fits nicely with what the devs were trying to do. Nothing really to say here.


=======

So
column31:
can I recommend "Red Lake" for purchase?
...What do you think?

Sorry

reviewText:
This is not a game for the faint of heart, it takes hours upon hours to complete if you want the best ending (not the dog being the mastermind, that's the second best). In order to even beat the first level, you're going to have to grind zombie dogs and stone bricks to even stand a chance against the sofa, which you're going to need to kill several times to get the neccessary drops. Once you have the shotgun (dropped by the couch), you can head upstairs and face the first boss... a piece of paper...

This paper is not to be underestimated, if you shoot it with the pistol, it won't even take damage. And if you interact with it, it will show you its message and kill you instantly. However, if you have the shotgun, you can exploit the ever popular stairs glitch and infinite ammo cheat to defeat it with ease, but the trouble doesn't end there... That was just chapter one...


Well, that's how I imagined the game was, in reality, the first level is impossible. and there's pretty much nothing to do.

reviewText:
I generally like to finish games before giving them a review, but damn.  This game.

It's one thing to have a game with some technical issues getting in the way of an otherwise great experience, like Deadly Premonition.  But this game is nearly impossible to progress in.  You have a laughably low fire rate with your pistol, which means you're highly unlikely to have a single encounter where you don't take damage.  This wouldn't be an issue if you actually had health kits to use, but in the short time I played, I didn't find one.  The controls are also very slippery besides that.  Movement feels like it takes place in an ice rink and aiming is a chore.

The scares are there.  But they're all jump scares with little to no thought put into them.  Things darting at you at high speed, bright flashes, all that.  The music isn't awful though.  Gotta get at least one thing (marginally) right.  I would tell you what the story is like, but by the time you get anywhere, you're at such low health that you eventually die in one hit, and most of the enemies (I only encountered dogs) don't give you any kind of indicator that they see you until they're already latched firmly onto your balls.  Also, you float up in the air when they attack you.  It's goofy.  Did I fail to mention that when you die, you go back to the beginning of the game?  Maybe there are checkpoints, but I can say from experience, they are in no way placed frequently enough.

Yet Red Lake is not the most lazy game I've played.  The developers do seem to actually care about the product.  They just did not deliver on making any of it refined in any sense of the word.  It's fundamentally broken.  I might revisit it with an iron gut and plow through the game just to see how it pans out and if there is anything that redeems it as a whole.

Get it for cheap in a bundle if you like bad games.  But if you want it for any reason outside of the novelty, stay away.

reviewText:
I would like to start my review off by acknowledging the developers for making the game so detailed and precise as the real world and also including Russian and English as the in-game languages (although it doesn't matter to me, I speak both).

I will write some of the pro's and con's of this realistic first person shooter and outline some key features that the game currently holds.

Pro's: This game has real time bullet ballistics and slow motion if you hit critical shots and feature bullet anatomy if the projectile fired is shattered upon impact of up to 3 enemies or more. The game is focused in a post apocalyptic world with unknown entities such as wild dogs which happen to look mutated, ghost-like in appearance dogs in really big caves and unknown sphere's which zap any breathing or moving object causing instant death or suffocation on the spot. The game also has very nice stealth mechanics which allow you to bypass enemies with ease but if you find yourself in a struggle for life, you can simply unload your chamber of 9mm rounds into the enemy causing internal tissue and muscle bleeding and external entry of bullet (wound). The reloading animation is some what hindered depending on your character's state which could be near death (i.e bitten by dogs or fallen off a certain height) or fully healthy (in which case it would be fast and smooth with no hesitation). You often write notes into your noteback after certain horrific events (i.e Sphere zaps multiple ghost-like dogs). You can read the latest events remembering the horror you bypassed by just clicking TAB which is the default binded key. The game also introduces a new mechanic which is masterbation! It helps with stress levels which your character has and can be increased if horrific anomalies are spotted such as a fat ghost flying across your screen. Of course, you can walk backwards and miss the whole point of this epic game but what boring person would want that?

Con's: This game only features 1 type of weapon which is the standard us military sidearm (The m9 beretta) which was first manufactured in Italy. Although more than 1 weapon would be cool, I don't mind having a sidearm as it's proven as one of the most effective throughout games and history itself.  Also I have a slight complaint about the sensitivity (too fast) but any person can get used to it as long as they use it plenty of times.

Summary: Realistic high quality anatomy,physics and ballistics of bullets and beautiful extraordinary graphics and gameplay, but the downside being the m9 as the only available weapon and slightly overly increased sensitivity.

Over my years of gaming, I have never played a game as detailed and amazing as red lake.
11/10.

Buy it, the recent update made the game even more stable and beautiful!

reviewText: 8/10\n\nThis could have been a better game if they added a little more enemies to shoot, but they focused more on the story. Would have given it a 9. Another thing that was annoying was picking up the ammo/weapons. It was not that responsive (took me a couple of times pressing the button to pick up the ammo/weapons). Everything else is great! Still playing it now. Favourite weapon is the ak. I'm not really into shotguns, but I hope they come up with a second game so they can continue on with the story.

reviewText:
This game absolutely blew me away.

First off, how i got this game was almost by fate. I bought a random Steam CD key from a G(2)A for fun and decided it was worth the investment. Boy, was I willy wonky right!!!

Red Lake provides nothing short of fantastic visuals, with it's realistic graphics, stunning 3D animations and A.I., bone-chilling and atmospheric music, in-depth and all out customizable controls, top of the line and detailed guns with only the most bountiful arsenal, and best of yet: breath taking gameplay.

This game had me on edge for every single minute that I invested in it and I will never regret having spent all those sweet and precious moments playing this game. In fact, this game was so ♥♥♥♥ing amazing that I didnt even want to beat it. Kinda like tearing out the last page of a book so it never ends :D

I would reccomend this life changing game to anyone and everyone. Kids, adults, seniors, whoever the person and whatever the age, this game fits all. To all of those that hate the game, they're just jealous of it's majesty and magnificence. Only nobodys would judge such a perfect and spotless game, they're all inferior.

This game took my heart and soul and gave back so much more.

12/10
voteText: 7 of 31 people (23%) found this review helpful 20 people found this review funny

reviewText:
If you're looking for a first person shooter to tide you over until Battlefront comes out, this is your game. I find it really tests my abilities as an elite gamer and forces me to perform at my best (In a good, unfrustrating way.)

The graphics, though not perfect, are realistic enough to make me really feel like I am there. The enemies are nothing short of terrifying, and the setting is downright spooky.

The gameplay is thrilling. You never know what is going to happen next, and a lot of things seem unintentional, and it never plays the same.

I may never need another first person shooter again.

Pros:
Good graphics
Solid gameplay
Realistic gun mechanics
Super scary

Cons:
The only problem I have with this game is that I can't find a problem with it

11/10
